comment: The Millet adds an interesting flavor I have not yet experienced with any bourbon. It might take some getting used to.
Smooth as hell! Sip this with. Nice fall meal.

The millet is a little odd. Almost sour, like dill pickles, but with a rich earthiness - newly sown mulch? Salt on the nose. Short finish, leaves you wanting more. 

Good to try, but not sure it's worth folding into the regular rotation.
The aroma is a little off compared to other bourbons. Definitely a little hot so I recommend ice. Could use more aging to smooth things out.

4/13/15. At DMK, in vibrant northern Chicago, this glass was a sip of smooth bliss after a LONG day of science speak. Caramel, toasty cereal and malty sweetness with a hint of wood spice afterburn. I only wish it was more complex, but simple whiskeys have a place in my home.

I don't know that I've ever hated a bourbon more than this one. The aroma reminded me more of gasoline than of anything resembling a drink I'd want twice in my lifetime. Between the wife and I, good bourbon doesn't survive for very long. Our bottle of Koval regularly gets called Abe Vigoda by the other bottles that move much more quickly in our collection.
Soft mouthfeel, less sweet than most bourbons thanks to the millet. Really smooth, hints of fruit. Really excellent
Not good. Very little nose. Aggressively poor flavor. The bad flavor starts in the middle of the tongue and progresses over all the tongue.

[LOOK] Thin syrup [NOSE] Paint thinner, banana peel, roast squash [PALATE] Pixie sticks, pizza dough, mineral water, vanilla, white pepper [FINISH]  Short, savory, surprising but not distinct [MOUTHFEEL] Resinous, light, powdery
Smells of chemicals and apple to me.  Flavors are not very complex - not particularly sweet or spicy.  Nothing really stands out much at all.
I love this bourbon... but it has a crazy amount of strength, spice and attitude, it really stands out.
Nice balanced taste, not excessively sweet at all. Complex flavor.

Nose- oak, vanilla, caramel, butterscotch, slight citrus.
Palate- oaky with wood spices, nutty, vanilla, caramel, salty, malted cereal, fresh sawdust.
Finish- more oak and spices vanilla and floral.

All in all I really had to search for the flavors but this being higher proof it's still very smooth. the wood over takes the flavor and the whiskey coats the tongue immediately. Not very complex at all but not a bad whiskey.
Very very spicy! Peppercorn, cinnamon. Some kind of fruit  candy. Long, long finish.
Had in Morristown. Very fruity. Delicious.
Maple, pecan and citrus on the nose. Butterscotch and tobacco on the tasting. Very simple sweet to smokey with a short finish. Not a fan.

Strange yet harmless combination of dill, vanilla, and dark caramel on the nose. Rich and warm mouthful, with sweet berries and holiday peppermint bark on the palate. Relatively long finish with delicate charred oak aftertaste. Really tasty. Original, organic, robust (47% ABV), well balanced, and worth trying, even for a non-Bourbon drinker like me.
A JD clone, not necessarily a bad thing, imo.
Tastes young. Not as deep or rich as I prefer
Sharp after taste. Fruity and sweet.
Nice pour. Clean taste and feel, the organic is a nice touch! Feels light and young, but a must try. It has a nice wood flavor that is a bit diff than the norm. 3.4/5

Very very good. Smooth, sweet and a nice long smooth vanilla and brown sugar finish. For such a young bourbon it drinks beyond it's years. Think of a more refined Larceny.  While this is not a wheated bourbon it sure drinks like one, minus the cereal notes. I even detect some BBQ smoke on the finish. Well played. 4.5/5
Hints of smoke remind me of some scotches, but otherwise unremarkable.

nose: overwhelming latex, pine, dissipates slightly to ripe banana.
taste: nutmeg, charred oak, dark cherry. heavy in mouth. caramel
finish: lingering warm mint, grapefruit, rind.
water: brings out caramel, some chocolate. latex persists.

very young bourbon but different enough to try. millet is not spicy as rye, but not overly sweet. tried in chicago, good to support local
As a Chicagoan, this is my go to above all others in its price range.  Distilled in a small neighborhood on the Northside of the city I call home.
Spicy finish - overall a nice slightly sweet bourbon

On the nose I got hints of brown sugar, vanilla, and banana laffy taffy.

taste has a rye quality with cherries.  very sweet.

I really enjoyed it!

Smells 100% like wood varnish or paint thinner. Smooth and unique. Very interesting flavor. Kind of a butterscotch flavor. I think I like it... very slightly peaty too. I wouldn’t seek this one out, but would buy a bottle if I happened to see it on the shelf.

Nose: Very Sweet, floral 
Taste: Spice
The chart notes are great in this one! Light finish too
Favorite go to whiskey. Never disappoints.
Wide depth of flavor - butterscotch, popcorn husk, melted butter.  But there is a paper note that I cannot get past.

the nose is soft, and slightly different than a typical bourbon. I'm guessing this is because the mash bill, they're using corn and Millet. It's pleasant but different from KSB. I'm not identifying specific notes which is interesting!  The taste is sweet and dry with no rye spice.  This is a smooth sipper that's pleasing and different... finish is a long short... atta boy chi-town! Next time I'm at Mission liquor in West Hills I'll pick up a bottle!

Sweet and fruity. 

Came in a three set package of Rye, Four Grain, and the Single Barrel Bourbon.
Grain forward.  Slightly sweet.  Stone fruit notes neat.  Slight caramel and tobacco notes on rocks
Vanilla, smoke, barrel & big caramel marshmallow booze finish. Loving this.
Not as smooth as I thought it would be, but lovely none the less. Will continue to drink.
Tastes a bit like brown vodka, but it’s local!

The nose is sweet of corn and cereal grains, with buttery creaminess, a hint of oak and the faintest trace of peach. The palate feels rich at first but quickly turns dry, as all of the sweet notes coat the mouth adding pleasant creaminess to the mouthfeel. The millet doesn’t make itself distinct but you can tell there is no rye or malted barely in this whiskey. The finish is somewhat short and releases some baking spices and buttery notes that linger while all of the sweetness quickly fades.

sweetest and smoothest Rye I've had. Really easy to drink.
Don't be disturbed by the wallpaper adhesive smell it comes with.

Nose:
Baking spices 
Caramel
Herbs
Almond-like nuttiness
Rice pudding
Light cherry

Palate:
Caramel
Leather
Earthiness
Herbs (rosemary, bay leaf)

Much better than some of Koval's other offerings (except the oat whiskey, which I forgot to rate). Actually prefer to the cask strength version.
Pleasantly warm overall. Definitely a spring or summer feel to it with the apricot and mango. No smoky winter flavors.

In summary, which I will do at the beginning as well as the end of this review, this is a stunning, fun to drink, juicy and sweet bourbon. I am generally not a fan of Bourbons perhaps because of the mash bill that emphasizes a spiciness and the Char of white oak barrels. But this one, along with Maker's Mark could be daily drinkers for me.

 LOL, if I could afford this one. I honestly don't know the price because I bought it as a 3-pack of 200 ml. bottles-- rye, bourbon and one other whiskey I don't recall at the moment. Hell, it was a weekend of Chicago Whiskey Fest in March 2018, how much of that could I possibly remember?? All were excellent!

Right off the bat, and a 47% ABV bottling, there's the usual bourbon turpentine, furniture polish, cherry wood furniture stain... All of this adds to the complexity and delights, not making it gross or chemical-smelling (other than wafts of bourbon-tainted ethanol) in any significant way. Certainly the alcohol is strong. But I have no desire to dilute this, the flavor is intense and delightful!

It must be the corn and Millet together, I wish more Bourbons or whiskeys of any sort used this mix. It would vastly enhance the taste and probably increase the customer base. (Women tend to enjoy sweeter drinks-- and cinnamon flavored whiskey, as well as brandy like Hot Damn is a hot seller among women, I hear.)

On to my review of the taste, which will be grossly insufficient due to my infamously coarse palate:

There is a richness and sweetness that does not resolve into specific tastes, though dates, mangoes and mild citrus fruits like kiwi come to mind.

Certainly the sweetness bears a resemblance to toffee and for some reason I want to keep on drinking and drinking and drinking this. They have done *something* right, although I cannot pinpoint the exact dimensions and contents and methods of their incredibly wiley alchemy, expressed as bourbon distilling perfection!

Let me admit this as a final perhaps fatal flaw in my taste buds, if only to entertain bourbon aficionados: I gave up my Chicago Whiskey Fest tasting pour, (the booth towards which hundreds literally ran!) the remainder of the Pappy Van Winkle 23-year old Family Reserve to my friend--because it essentially did *nothing* great for me. I knew he would enjoy it and for a whiskey that sells currently at $2,800-$4000 a bottle, my lack of appreciation was almost a crime! 

In praise of Koval, I would trade, if based on taste alone (certainly I would make an investment calculation in the real world!) that 23 y.o. Pappy for half a bottle of Koval bourbon! That's how damn freaking good this stuff is!

Okay, it may be faint praise for Koval from an (evident) "sherryhead" with only three to four years intensive whiskey tasting experience. Be that as it may, should this whiskey gain a widespread audience, it could surpass Maker's Mark as THE entry level whiskey for bourbon beginners, and perhaps help create an entire new, expanding market for bourbon that omitts rye and adds varying levels of complexity, variation and sweetness,  based in this case on millet, grain I find far more appealing (mostly because it's sweeter) than the rye portion of the mash bill in most bourbons.

Nose: Chocolate, orange peel, caramels, burnt marshmallows. It's like a fruity burnt smore.

Taste: hints of caramel and sour apples, with a strong cereal or cake batter body ending very quickly in a smokey citrus.

Experience: I've never eaten fruit with s'mores, or even by a campfire at all. But that is the direction it takes. It's not a bad ride, but a short one for sure. The proof feels lower than it is.
Apricot, corn and a great port finish...I’m a fan.
Nose not great, but flavor is better. Great vanilla and barrel char with an odd/interesting grain note from the millet. Don’t love it or hate it.
Vanilla and everything good in the word
Tasty barrel notes in this one

It’s definitely a cool addition to the collection, as it has a unique flavor. Neat - Sweet but not the caramel flavors your used to. Had a smooth finish.  
Coke splash - nope. Definitely a sipper
Sweet with toffee notes followed by slight bite
Enjoyable but somewhat astringent. Would happily drink when available.
Spicy, but could use a bit more punch. Smooth.
Heavy on caramel with a little oakiness. Pretty smooth at 95 proof. Enjoyably unique.
Light flavor and has a bite. Not very smooth.
Late check-in from Sav / Dimellio Fam dinner... #Dinner #Celestial

Starting neat, adding one small ice cube halfway.
Nose: Brown sugar and vanilla.
Palate: Subtle and lingering spice. The warmth of a Hot Toddy comes to surface with waves of licorice. Sugar, licorice, and anise increase as the ice melts and trades places with the spice.
Finish: Spice of licorice and clove remain to the end of the glass. 
Overall surpasses the expectations for a bourbon aged under 4 years.
Spicier than other bourbons I’ve had with a peaty vanilla flavor
Fruity and pleasantly unusual; a great change of pace for hot days.

Nose: Vanilla and caramel, lots of vanilla! Subtle notes of coffee and pine needle.

Palate: Very rich.  Lots of oak initially then moving to sweet toasted coconut.

Finish: Fairly short and thin. Not much happening here. Some lingering bitter orange peel on the back of the palate. 

Overall I find this bourbon very enjoyable and a nice change from other bourbons. Maybe the millet and lack of rye coming in here. Certainly would recommend!
Thanks Tim! Enjoying the patio at @OtisDB hacienda.
Vanilla, sweet bread, lemon, and oak spice.
Damp, old wood.  Like walking through an abandoned house in the forest.
